Moreover, if the mind of that god has the thought of descending into the sky, as soon as he thinks of it, he will descend from the sky together with the heavenly multitudes. After descending, he will return to his own dwelling place and stay there.
In this way, the precious pearl will return to its original state and have great radiance.
The heavenly maidens have thus spoken to the newly born god.
At that time, the newly born god, bound by the noose of desire, will again delight in the objects and go to the forest of precious jewels.

He will see that not far away, there are countless hundreds of thousands of yellow, red, and white lights filling the forest of precious jewels. Not far from that forest of precious jewels, there is a forest of geese.
At that time, the newly born god, having heard this from the heavenly maidens, will go to the forest of precious jewels and go there together with the heavenly maidens.
Having arrived there, he sees the boundless radiance of the jewel. At that time, the newly born god thinks like this:
'Just as those other gods enter the jewel forest in the sky and travel everywhere, seeing the heavenly realms, so shall I enter the jewel forest and travel in this way.'
As soon as he thinks this, in accordance with his thoughts, the jewel becomes a palace in the sky.
The newly born god sees this in the sky and enters the jewel palace together with the celestial maidens.
According to his own good karma, he sees various delightful things in the palace.
In that jewel there are flowing rivers, lotus ponds, gardens, forests, and mountain peaks filling the jewel palace. His eyes see and his mind delights.
Furthermore, in various places he sees birds with lovely voices.
In such places there are various colors, shapes, fragrances, and flowers.

They also see other places with various birds and beasts, some with gentle riverbanks and some with steep riverbanks, all of which are delightful. On the riverbanks they see other places where many gods and goddesses sing, dance, laugh, play, and enjoy pleasures.
In such places, all the gardens and forests are just as described above. When the gods first see this, they play, enjoy pleasures, and indulge with the goddesses, never knowing enough of desire.
They also go to other places, and then go to the place of food called Sudha, in order to eat.
They obtain food that is similar to their own good karma.
After eating that food, burned by the fire of objects, they go to the wine river again, together with the goddesses, carried by the waves of desire, to the place where they drink wine by the river.
Having arrived there, they then drink wine from jeweled vessels.

Having drunk the wine, their joyful minds become even more elated. Burned by the fire of desire for objects, deluded by the five sense objects, they again sing, dance, and play with the celestial maidens.
Having thus enjoyed heavenly pleasures there, they again go toward the lotus ponds and forests.
Desiring to play in those ponds, together with the celestial maidens they experience the pleasures of the five senses, and thus they go toward the lotus ponds and forests.

Having arrived, they again experience the pleasures of the objects of the senses. Together with the celestial maidens they play in the water, with the most excellent pleasures that cannot be compared, experiencing such pleasures.

Moreover, they give rise to desire, hope for pleasure, desire to hear sounds, and are attached to the objects of the five kinds of music. They mentally long to hear the singing voices of the celestial maidens.
Having heard the sounds of the five kinds of music, their minds are delighted beyond description, and there is no other phenomenon that can be used as a comparison.
They experience such five sense pleasures and various supreme pleasures, yet they are never satisfied.
Because of desire, desire knows no satisfaction, just as fire has no satiation when it obtains fuel.
In this way, desire is insatiable. One always experiences various kinds of pleasures with immeasurable distinctions.
After experiencing such pleasures for a long time, they sit again in the pearl hall in the swan forest.
Together with the celestial maidens, they descend from the pearl hall, enter the swan forest, and see an unprecedented place.
Having seen such a place, their minds give rise to joy and delight in this way. Having seen various things in this way, they are still not satisfied with their objects.
In this way, the places with flowing water, lotus ponds, and gardens and forests, when the gods and celestial maidens see the sounds of the five kinds of music, they play in this way.
Moreover, the king of geese resides in a vast place, and the gods together with the goddesses go to that place of the geese.
In this way, in that place one sees various gods, with hundreds of thousands of them singing, dancing, playing, and enjoying heavenly pleasures, with no other objects that can serve as analogies.
Their forms surpass those of worldly suns, like fireflies, with only their light remaining, with no other analogies.
In that place, the pleasures that are experienced are incomparable, with analogies for the gods who experience those pleasures being unobtainable.

The best flavors in the human world, namely the flavors of honey, medicinal wine, sugarcane, meat, etc., are the best flavors in JambudvÄ«pa, but when combined with red suta, they are no different from extremely bitter flavors and astringent flavors.
The best flavors in the human world are inferior in this way to the heavenly flavors.
In this way, the superiority of the flavors is only a partial analogy, with the flavors in the heavens being incomparable.

The fragrance of those gods is also incomparable. For example, the best fragrance in the human world is that of sandalwood, agarwood, powdered incense, ointments, champak flowers, niqiusidi flowers, and sumana flowers. Such as gandhabbas, lotuses, udumbara flowers, and nyagrodhas, all of these flowers combined are still not as fragrant as the flowers in the heavens.
In those heavens, the fragrance of the renpo-colored flowers is not even a sixteenth of that. In this way, the fragrance in the heavens is also incomparable.
Moreover, the touch in those heavens is also incomparable.

In the human world, the most excellent touch of all lands is that of silk, cotton, and wool. Such various touches in the human realm are extremely inferior in that heaven, referring to the hardest gold, which is still inferior to the most excellent touch in the human realm.
The touch in the human realm is not even one-sixteenth of that in the heavens. Such touches in the heavens are beyond analogy.
Moreover, the sounds in that heaven are also beyond analogy.

The best sounds in the human world are those of the lute, zither, flute, pipa, drums, and singing. Even if all such sounds were combined, they would still be inferior to the sounds of the adornments in that heaven.
The sounds of the adornments in that heaven are not even one-sixteenth of that. Such sounds in the heavens are beyond analogy.

Constantly enjoying sensual pleasures, unaware that time has passed.
In regard to karma and karmic retribution, never having any understanding,
Only greedy for the taste of food, not aware that time has passed.
Blown by the wind of karma, always in this triple realm,
Transmigrating like a wheel, ignorant and unaware.
Always in evil places, on high beams and ropes,
Thus the foolish do not diligently abandon faults.
If one can abandon desires, this is the foremost diligence,
Free from all hopes and wishes, then there are no afflictions.
At the beginning, middle, and end, if one attains the Buddha's teachings,
Because of peacefully practicing, this is one without afflictions.
If one attains sensual pleasures, those pleasures will certainly be destroyed,
Because of desires one obtains painful retribution, knowing desires are not supreme dharmas.
Therefore the wise do not delight in desires in their minds,
They are then able to cut off the causes and conditions of suffering in birth and death.
The great goose king spoke this verse to the newly born god, criticizing the dharma of desire in this way.
The newly born god gradually approached the goose king.

Although the newly born god heard the excellent dharma, his mind did not accept it. Confused by objects, he gradually approached the goose king but did not grasp the dharma. Still attached to objects, he enjoyed the pleasures of desire.
He saw the goose king playing in the water, entering the lotus forest, plucking lotuses, and throwing them with the group of heavenly maidens.
The goose king Good Time said to him:
'You do not accept this beneficial advice. What will you gain later?'
At that time, the newly born god in the bird realm again heard an excellent and wonderful sound from a distance, surpassing the sound of the gods.
Having heard that sound, he felt joy in his heart. The sound pervaded everywhere, like the lovely sounds of a pipa, a konghou, a qin, a drum, a flute, and so on.
At that time, the gods were playing by the side of the vast pond. Having heard the sound, they all turned their faces to listen to the sound.

At that time, they saw from afar hundreds of thousands of halls surrounding them. The heavenly singing sounds were extremely delightful, and those who heard it wanted to give rise to [the mind of enlightenment].

It was as upright, majestic, and wonderful as stars surrounding the moon. In this way, the halls surrounded them, either with the light of their bodies surrounding them like a wheel. The minds of all the heavenly beings were delighted, and hundreds of thousands of heavenly maidens sang.

'The king of geese universally benefits all the gods of the Heaven of YÄma, and benefits all the gods of the Heaven of YÄma. Therefore he is here now, and we should return together to the great lake.'

Having said this, the night-shining god king surrounded by countless gods and goddesses, and the king of good time geese surrounded by countless hundreds of thousands of geese, these two kings each with their retinue, in harmony with each other, in the sky with various sounds, their minds all free from defilements like a jewel, on the ground of indulgence practicing non-indulgence, with great authority, together went to the great lake.

Having arrived at the great lake, all the gods there, seeing the god king temporarily stopping indulgence, not making sounds, not amusing each other, not playing in the water in various ways, gave rise to a respectful mind.
The night-shining god king, knowing that the minds of those gods were well-disciplined, said to the king of geese:
'Good time, King of Geese!
This time is best, now you can speak the Dharma.
The heavenly beings see me, their minds all free from arrogance, and the assembly of heavenly maidens are all without arrogance, you can speak the Dharma for them.'

At that time, the king of geese thought of his past life, having once in the past heard various Dharma gates from a Buddha named KÄÅ›yapa. Of the Dharmas he heard, he only used one Dharma to speak for the assembly of gods.
He said to the king of gods:
'King of gods, listen well, I will now speak for you.
There are five kinds of dharmas. If gods or humans practice heedlessly, this is a fundamental fault.
What are the five?
Namely, the heedless one's mind is then confused, thinking of different dharmas with the mind, while speaking different words with the mouth.
If there is something to be said, it is untrue and meaningless, contradicting each other before and after, fluctuating and uncertain, and others will not accept it.
Why is this?
Because the heedless mind is agitated and confused.
They do not know what they are saying or to whom they are speaking, and so they are despised and rejected.
Because of this, they become self-deprecating, which is the fault of negligence.
Because of the fault of negligence, they fall into the evil destinies and are born in the three evil realms according to their affinities.
This is the first fault.
There is a second fault of negligence.
What is the second?
It is called not knowing what should be done and what should not be done.
Because of a negligent mind, one does not know what should be done and what should not be done.
One does not know what karma is and what its fruits are. Because of not knowing karma, one does not know its fruits.
Because of being deluded about karma and its fruits, when the fool's body perishes and life ends, he falls into the evil destinies and is born in the hells.
Because of negligence, one obtains such faults. This is the second fault.
There is a third fault of negligence.
What is the third?
If a person or god, due to negligence, associates with bad friends, does not respect the Three Jewels, does not seek wisdom, does not respect elders,
does not perceive or know the virtues of the past,
does not give rise to disgust with the suffering of birth and death,
does not understand mixed karma, namely various karmas,
is unable to be diligent, always delights in sleep, and is unable to uphold precepts.
When the body perishes and life ends, one falls into a bad realm and is born in hell.
Because of negligence, one obtains such faults. This is the third fault.
Moreover, that negligence has a fourth fault.
What is the fourth?
It means that in the heavens or among humans, as soon as one is born, the life force does not abide, and as soon as it is born it perishes. Good karma is also like this;
as soon as it is born it is exhausted. The king of death is about to arrive. With whom will one be negligent?
One will certainly be separated from them.
There are four things that will definitely separate one from them. What are the four?
First, youth;
second, comfort;
third, lifespan;
fourth, completeness.
These four will definitely separate one from them. The wise always observe these four. If one is negligent, one will not be able to know.
If gods or humans engage in negligence, they will not know anything. Because of not knowing, they will fall into evil paths.
Because of negligence, one obtains such faults. This is the fourth fault.
Moreover, that negligence has a fifth fault.
What is the fifth?
It means to trust in the most untrustworthy place.
The most untrustworthy among the untrustworthy are women. Yet foolish people trust women.
Although foolish people trust women, women do not trust them. Until the end of their lives, their minds are not free from deception.
All women are full of flattery and deception, full of impurity and destruction, their minds full of arrogance and broken precepts.
Such faults are not absent from the minds of all women, just as fire is hot. Women are not free from these things.
If a foolish person trusts such women, there is only talk, but not a single truth.
Because of love and greed, they are dragged around by desire, and therefore they get close to them.
Thus, in brief, the conduct of heedlessness has five kinds of faults. These five faults are not apart from heedlessness. Therefore, gods and humans should abandon heedlessness.

This conduct of heedlessness obstructs the gate to nirvana. One who practices heedlessness, when the body perishes and life ends, falls into a bad realm of existence, and is born in the hells, as a hungry ghost, or as an animal.
Because of heedlessness, one obtains such faults. This is the fifth fault.
Therefore, the wise should abandon heedlessness. If one abandons heedlessness, there are five merits.
What are the five?
They are right practice, right mind, right faith, doing what should be done, not doing what should not be done, always applying the mind, and benefiting all at all times.
Abandoning negligence as if it were poison, and understanding the three times.
This is the first merit of being diligent, and it is attained because of diligence.
Moreover, the second merit of being diligent is:
What is the second?
It is knowing light and heavy.
Approaching good friends, always doing good deeds;
Avoiding bad friends, not doing bad deeds, because those bad deeds are despised by good people.
If one sees bad people, one should abandon them all, and if one sees virtuous people, one should be close to them.
Practicing in this way with a good mind, one will not enter the evil paths.
This is the second merit of being diligent, and it is attained because of diligence.
Moreover, the third merit of being diligent is:
What is the third?
It is called carefulness.
Even at the cost of one's life, one should not be under the control of women, nor believe their words.
At all times, one should observe that all women have two kinds of bonds that bind the world.
Only seeing their appearance, not believing their words, the wise one observes women in this way, as they truly are.
Having observed in this way, as it truly is, even if one sees singing, dancing, joy, laughter, play, adornments, and so forth, one's mind does not become attached.
All carelessness is caused by women, all women are half-carelessness.
If one is able to leave behind the carelessness of women, then one will be able to cross over the great ocean of birth and death.
In the human world, people all say:
The careful one is called a good person.
This is the third merit of carefulness. Because of carefulness, one attains this merit.
The fourth merit is that of carefulness.
What is the fourth?
It is called being careful and not negligent. It means not having faith in wealth, pleasure, desires, etc., observing them as impermanent, and knowing this:
These desires are impermanent, changing, and unstable, so they cannot be trusted. They will soon be destroyed and lost.
In this way, one does not have faith in things that are peaceful and secure, so one is not negligent.

All that is peaceful and secure is destroyed by illness. In this way, one does not give rise to faith in even a little. All youth is destroyed by old age, so one does not give rise to a conceited mind in youth.
In this way, one does not give rise to faith or a conceited mind in life, and does not commit evil deeds.
Why is this?
Because one will certainly be robbed by the king of death.
Therefore, one does not have faith in all conditioned dharmas of birth and death. Because of having no faith, one practices being careful and not negligent.
This is the fourth merit of being careful and not negligent. Because of being careful and not negligent, one attains this merit.
The fifth merit of non-negligence is:
What is the fifth?

It is said that one always associates with sages and delights in wisdom, takes refuge in the Three Jewels, hears the Dharma and contemplates its meaning. When one is about to die, one does not give rise to fear.
Because one knows the signs of death and the signs of retrogression, one does not give rise to fear.

The Heaven of Hearing the Sounds of Dharma knows the signs of retrogression, and when a person is about to die, one knows the signs of death. Knowing in this way, one knows rebirth in evil destinies and rebirth in good destinies, knowing like this:
I am reborn in a good destiny.
I am reborn in an evil destiny.

If at the time of death, the signs of an evil destiny appear, one is able to skillfully purify the mind. Because the mind is purified, the signs of an evil destiny are extinguished, and the signs of a good destiny appear.
This is the supreme fruit of non-negligence, which is very difficult to attain. Among all good friends, this is also the best.
This is the fifth merit of being diligent, which is attained due to diligence.
' At that time, the king of good time geese recited the verses spoken by the Tathagata Kakacanda Buddha:
'The Tathagata who has already left desires praises diligence,
And criticizes negligent conduct, wherever one goes in the cycle of birth and death.
Because of diligence one attains liberation, because of negligence one experiences suffering,
This negligence binds one, the foolish are unable to cut it off.
The diligent good person is born among the gods,
Because of negligence among the gods, one then regrets when falling back.
All those who are negligent cannot escape the cycle of birth and death,
Negligence is the foremost snare that can bind one and cause one to transmigrate.
Doing what should not be done, not doing what should be done,
All those who are negligent do everything in the opposite way.
They do not even engage in worldly affairs, let alone supramundane ones.
Therefore, the wise do not praise indulging in carelessness.
For this reason, one should not engage in careless conduct.
Such careless conduct is the first messenger of the evil paths.
If there are those who can abandon the abode of suffering and distress,
Such a valiant one can cross the great ocean of existence.'
The king of geese, Good Time, thus spoke to the lord of the gods, Muzhoulou Tuo, and the assembly of gods, about the old Dharma of the past, benefiting gods and humans.
Moreover, the king of geese, appearing as the lord of the gods, Muzhoulou Tuo, further spoke the Dharma, saying:
'There are five kinds of dharmas that counteract the careless conduct of Å›ramaá¹‡as.
What are the five?
Namely, all those who indulge carelessly will experience suffering.
Such a person, following any carelessness, can lead to suffering.
Abandoning that heedlessness, knowing its faults, cultivating merit, and abandoning it, there is nothing that is not beneficial;
not experiencing suffering and distress, unwholesome evil karma will not increase, and one will cultivate right practice.
This is the first counteractive method of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, the counteraction of heedlessness.
Moreover, the second counteractive method of the Å›ramaá¹‡a is the counteraction of heedlessness.
What is the second?
It is called seeing the truth.
A person who truly sees will have all their thoughts and intentions decisively see things as they truly are.
Because of seeing things as they truly are, they will not engage in heedlessness, because they see the faults of heedlessness as they truly are.
This is the second counteraction of heedlessness.
Moreover, the third counteractive method of the Å›ramaá¹‡a is the counteraction of heedlessness.
What is the third?
It is called associating with the heedful, receiving precepts and upholding them.
Acting as they act, doing as they do,
They always stay with those who uphold precepts and avoid being close to those who violate precepts.
Therefore, all forms of negligence are absent.
This is the third remedy for negligence.
Moreover, monks, the fourth remedy is to counteract negligence.
What is the fourth?
It means that in order to seek wisdom, one always stays close to the wise, always delights in the wise, and abandons negligence.
Those who stay close to the diligent and careful who are not negligent, who delight in the good and avoid suffering, such good men always practice in this way without negligence.
This is the fourth remedy for negligence.
Moreover, monks, the fifth remedy is to counteract negligence.
What is the fifth?

It means that if a king or a king's minister seizes a negligent person, he will punish him, perhaps taking his life, perhaps confiscating all his property, perhaps beating him, perhaps cutting off his hands.
In this way, various punishments are different for the negligent. Seeing this, they become fearful.
Because of fear, they abandon negligence and practice non-negligence.
In this way, they abandon negligence by means of antidotes, seeing others receive such punishments and becoming fearful.
In accordance with the Dharma, they fear that negligent conduct will lead to falling into hell, and therefore do not engage in any evil conduct.
This is the fifth antidote to negligence.
In this way, negligence is not peaceful for gods or humans.'
When the many gods heard this sutra, they abandoned negligence.

Having heard the sutra spoken by the goose king, the night spirit king of the Heaven of Joy gave rise to a mind of delight and, together with the assembly of gods, flew up into the sky, returning as they had come.
The other gods, some continued to enjoy pleasures in the vast pond, while others went to the forest to enjoy pleasures.
Having entered the garden, they experience various pleasures in this way, until finally their good karma is exhausted.
